Award.AwardTitle: Mobility of Pyroclastic Density Currents: Integrating Field and Experimental Techniques to Understand the Controls and Consequences of Erosion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs) are the most dangerous hazard associated with explosive volcanism. These unpredictable currents consist of searing hot clouds of gas, ash and rock that travel down the slopes of erupting volcanoes with tremendous force and velocity. The driving force for these devastating currents is their dense nature (due to the mixture of ash and rock) relative to the ambient air. PDCs will travel across the landscape, potentially many miles beyond the volcano flanks, until the ash and rock within the current has dropped out and the current density decreases to match that of the ambient air. Despite the pervasiveness of PDCs and their deadly consequences, many fundamental aspects of their behavior and controls on runout distance remain poorly understood. One of the most important gaps in our understanding of these currents is the mechanism(s) for eroding into the surface over which a PDC flows, and the influence of mixing substrate material into the current on downstream flow dynamics. Given that the primary control on runout distance is a current?s density relative to the ambient air, bulking of the current due to entrainment of the substrate would influence and possibly extend the ultimate runout distance, thereby increasing destructive potential. This work combines field techniques and scaled laboratory experiments to examine the complex relationships between PDC conditions and erosion, and the consequence of erosion on current mobility.

This project will explore the control of three main parameters on a current's ability to erode from the substrate: slope, degree of fluidization (pore pressure), and nature of the substrate (particle size, particle density, thickness of erodible bed and substrate roughness). This work will be conducted in three phases. The first phase includes field studies on the well-exposed PDC deposits from the May 18th, 1980 eruption of Mt St Helens (MSH), which builds on the previous work on these deposits of the lead investigator. Field work includes textural, granulometry and componentry studies to determine (or infer) the source of eroded lithics within the PDC deposits, the substrate conditions that favor erosion (e.g., slope, surface roughness) and the influence of erosion on downstream flow dynamics of the eroding PDCs. The second phase involves scaled experiments to explore the general conditions that favor erosion via shear at the base versus underpressure in the head of fluidized currents, which build on the fundamental work of collaborator Dr. Roche. The third phase includes experiments that specifically explore our interpretations and hypothesis developed from the phase one field results from MSH by assessing (1) the influence of topographic obstacles on erosion and downstream flow dynamics, (2) the role of an increased density gradient on basal shear stress and erosion, and (3) the development of fabric in laboratory flows as a function of degree of fluidization and interaction with obstacles. The ultimate goal is to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the controls on PDC damage potential and runout distance, which will enable better assessments and mitigation of the hazards associated with future explosive eruptions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs), hot, ground-hugging flows of gas, ash and rock, are the most dangerous hazard associated with explosive volcanism.  We applied field work, geophysical techniques, and scaled laboratory experiments to constrain influence of topography and substrate erosion on PDC flow behavior and hazard potential. We also developed a new technique to lithify unconsolidated deposits and conduct fabric (particle shape) analysis, which allowed us to constrain flow direction. 

We found that PDCs at Mount St Helens were erosive where they accelerated along steep flanks (>25°) and interacted with irregular topography, suggesting high velocity and basal shear stress are important controls on erosive capacity. Geophysical techniques that image the subsurface reveal that PDCs can erode broad, extensive channels in underlying soft sediments. The two PDC erosional channels identified at Mount St Helens are larger than any previously documented PDC erosional features, and support the hypothesis that PDCs are capable of eroding channels that can confine and potentially extend the runout distance and velocity of subsequent flows. Finally, scaled laboratory experiments further reveal that substrate erosion, like that found at Mount St Helens, results from underpressure behind the current head and increased shear stress due to high velocities. More importantly, experiments reveal that substrate erosion has the potential to increase the bulk density of PDCs, increasing both runout distance and damage potential. These results have implications for constraining the hazard potential of PDCs at volcanoes worldwide. 

Our work resulted in eight published papers (four first authored by students) with three additional papers in preparation, and one popular media article published in The Conversation. Our research team also produced 27 professional presentations at conferences or institutions (11 invited), two graduate theses, and one dissertation thesis in preparation.  The project benefited from the involvement and training of one Ph.D. student, one M.S. student, and three undergraduate students, as well as the collaboration of Drs. Roche (Laboratoire Magmas et Volcans, France), Sarrochi (Geology Institute at Universidad Autonóma de San Luis Potosi, Mexico), Bradford (Boise State University), Sulpizio (Università degli Studi di Bari Aldo Moro, Bari, Italy), Rowley (University of Hull, England), and Giordano (Università Degli Studi Roma Tre Rome, Italy) and their students. Brand and students led annual field trips for the general public through the Mount St Helens Institute, and participated in the United States Geological Survey (USGS) Cascade Volcano Observatory GeoGirls program in 2015. Brand and Ph.D. student Pollock also led two professional field trips, one for the Pacific Northwest volcanology group in 2012, and another for the IAVCEI meeting in 2017. The IAVCEI field trip included 35 international volcanologists and their students. The purpose of both field professional field trips was to bring together the world leaders in volcanology and students to explore and discuss the hazards associated with explosive volcanism, and apply what we learn at Mt St Helens to volcanoes worldwide. Products include a peer reviewed field guide published by the USGS, an article published in the BSU FOCUS magazine (https://focus.boisestate.edu/article/out-of-the-classroom-into-the-field/), a blog post on our BSU Volcanic and Magmatic Studies page, and a four-minute video documenting our experience for the general public (https://youtu.be/VyTXlb_Ur5g).
